pullrequest.title: Logging Part 3: Getting all messages from a log file

content.raw:
We should prefer just `"BatchPrivate.hh"` here since it's in the same directory as the source file. It's strange that the `log` directory would be one of the build include directories, and that could easily change if we audit or modify our build scripts.

I'll get rid of the `src/`.

Edit: Done 8059c23
content.html:
We should prefer just "BatchPrivate.hh" here since it's in the same directory as the source file. It's strange that the log directory would be one of the build include directories, and that could easily change if we audit or modify our build scripts.

I'll get rid of the src/.

Edit: Done 8059c23

content.raw: We're using an rvalue reference to allow `_statements` to be moved. That is significantly more efficient than a const-reference function argument. Also, rvalue references cannot be const.
content.html: We're using an rvalue reference to allow _statements to be moved. That is significantly more efficient than a const-reference function argument. Also, rvalue references cannot be const.

pullrequest.title: Logging Part 3: Getting all messages from a log file

content.raw:
I added documentation instead of changing the constructor to copy data in 6a952fb06639.

This constructor is used by `MsgIter`. The pointers are for data are held by SQLite3, are borrowed, and are only valid until the `MsgIter` is stepped to the next result. This is handy for a user that queried all messages from one topic. Since they're all the same type and topic name the user will never call `Topic()` or `Type()`. Not including them in the constructor saves those copies from being made.

`MsgIter` returns a const reference to a `Message` which combined with the lack of copy and move constructors prevents a user from holding onto these pointers. In c3117e4b9a0a the copy and move constructors are explicitly deleted with documentation instead of implicitly deleted.
content.html:
I added documentation instead of changing the constructor to copy data in 6a952fb06639.

This constructor is used by MsgIter. The pointers are for data are held by SQLite3, are borrowed, and are only valid until the MsgIter is stepped to the next result. This is handy for a user that queried all messages from one topic. Since they're all the same type and topic name the user will never call Topic() or Type(). Not including them in the constructor saves those copies from being made.

MsgIter returns a const reference to a Message which combined with the lack of copy and move constructors prevents a user from holding onto these pointers. In c3117e4b9a0a the copy and move constructors are explicitly deleted with documentation instead of implicitly deleted.

pullrequest.title: Logging Part 3: Getting all messages from a log file

content.raw:
This class is like a spoof of `std::variant` (which isn't available until C++17). It will only contain one of these value types. So if the object is actually containing a `Real` or a `Text` value, then it will not be containing an `Integer` value, so we should not allow the class to return a value or reference to an integer. Instead, it will return a `nullptr`, which the consumer should take as an indication that the object is storing a different type of parameter.

Ideally, the consumer should check the `Type()` function before asking for any of the values, but we cannot guarantee that they will do so.
content.html:
This class is like a spoof of std::variant (which isn't available until C++17). It will only contain one of these value types. So if the object is actually containing a Real or a Text value, then it will not be containing an Integer value, so we should not allow the class to return a value or reference to an integer. Instead, it will return a nullptr, which the consumer should take as an indication that the object is storing a different type of parameter.

Ideally, the consumer should check the Type() function before asking for any of the values, but we cannot guarantee that they will do so.

pullrequest.title: Logging Part 3: Getting all messages from a log file

content.raw: The state of an object is undefined after it has been moved from (this is a C++ language rule). We shouldn't place any expectations on `param_orig` after we've moved from it.
content.html: The state of an object is undefined after it has been moved from (this is a C++ language rule). We shouldn't place any expectations on param_orig after we've moved from it.
